docx_questions.text: How does chest wall compliance in an infant differ from that of an adult?
options: 𝛼. An adult’s chest wall compliance is lower than an infant’s. 𝗉. An adult’s chest wall compliance is higher than an infant’s.
n adult’s chest wall compliance is the same as an infant’s. 𝛿. An adult’s chest wall compliance is dissimilar to that of an infant’s.

docx_questions.text: Why is nasal congestion a serious threat to young infants?
options: 𝛼. Infants are obligatory nose breathers.
𝗉. Their noses are small in diameter.
Infants become dehydrated when mouth breathing.
𝛿. Their epiglottis is proportionally greater than the epiglottis of an adult’s.

docx_questions.text: The risk for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) decreases for premature infants when they are born between how many weeks of gestation?
Which type of croup is most common?
What is the chief predisposing factor for respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) of the newborn?
options: 𝗉. Alcohol consumption during pregnancy c. Premature birth

docx_questions.text: What is the primary cause of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) of the newborn?
Which option shows the correct sequence of events after atelectasis develops in respiratory distress syndrome of the newborn?
options: 𝛼. Increased pulmonary vascular resistance, atelectasis, hypoperfusion 𝗉. Hypoxic vasoconstriction, right-to-left shunt hypoperfusion c. Respiratory acidosis, hypoxemia, hypercapnia
𝛿. Right-to-left shunt, hypoxic vasoconstriction, hypoperfusion

docx_questions.text: Which statement about the advances in the treatment of respiratory distress syndrome (RDS) of the newborn is incorrect?
options: 𝛼. Administering glucocorticoids to women in preterm labor accelerates the maturation of the fetus’s lungs.
𝗉. Administering oxygen to mothers during preterm labor increases their arterial oxygen before the birth of the fetus.
Treatment includes the instillation of exogenous surfactant down an endotracheal tube of infants weighing less than 1000 g.
𝛿. Using continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) supports the infant’s respiratory function.

docx_questions.text: Bronchiolitis tends to occur during the first years of life and is most often caused by what type of infection?
Which immunoglobulin (Ig) is present in childhood asthma?
Which T-lymphocyte phenotype is the key determinant of childhood asthma?
options: 𝛼. Cluster of differentiation (CD) 4 T-helper Th1 lymphocytes 𝗉. CD4 T-helper Th2 lymphocytes c. CD8 cytotoxic T lymphocytes 𝛿. Memory T lymphocytes

docx_questions.text: Which cytokines activated in childhood asthma produce an allergic response?
options: 𝛼. Interleukin (IL)–1, IL-2, and interferon-alpha (IFN-𝛼) 𝗉. IL-8, IL-12, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-𝛼) c. IL-4, IL-10, and colony-stimulating factor (CSF) 𝛿. IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13

docx_questions.text: Which statement accurately describes childhood asthma?
options: 𝛼. An obstructive airway disease characterized by reversible airflow obstruction, bronchial hyperreactivity, and inflammation
𝗉. A pulmonary disease characterized by severe hypoxemia, decreased pulmonary compliance, and diffuse densities on chest x-ray imaging
pulmonary disorder involvinNgURanSIaNbGnToBrm.CaOlMexpression of a protein, producing viscous mucus that lines the airways, pancreas, sweat ducts, and vas deferens
𝛿. An obstructive airway disease characterized by atelectasis and increased pulmonary resistance as a result of a surfactant deficiency

docx_questions.text: Which criterion is used to confirm a diagnosis of asthma in an 8-year-old child?
options: 𝗉. Serum testing that confirms increased immunoglobulin E (IgE) and eosinophil levels
Reduced expiratory flow rates confirmed by spirometry testing 𝛿. Improvement on a trial of asthma medication

docx_questions.text: Which statement best describes acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS)?
options: 𝛼. An obstructive airway disease characterized by reversible airflow obstruction, bronchial hyperreactivity, and inflammation
𝗉. A pulmonary disease characterized by severe hypoxemia, decreased pulmonary compliance, and the presence of bilateral infiltrates on chest x-ray imaging
respiratory disorder involving an abnormal expression of a protein producing viscous mucus that lines the airways, pancreas, sweat ducts, and vas deferens
𝛿. A pulmonary disorder characterized by atelectasis and increased pulmonary resistance as a result of a surfactant deficiency

docx_questions.text: When considering the signs and symptoms of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), the absence of which condition is considered characteristic?
options: 𝛼. Progressive respiratory distress c. Decreased pulmonary compliance 𝗉. Bilateral infiltrates d. Heart failure

docx_questions.text: Which statement best describes cystic fibrosis?
options: 𝛼. Obstructive airway disease characterized by reversible airflow obstruction, bronchial hyperreactivity, and inflammation
𝗉. Respiratory disease characterized by severe hypoxemia, decreased pulmonary compliance, and diffuse densities on chest x-ray imaging
Pulmonary disorder involving an abnormal expression of a protein-producing viscous mucus that obstructs the airways, pancreas, sweat ducts, and vas deferens
𝛿. Pulmonary disorder characterized by atelectasis and increased pulmonary resistance as a result of a surfactant deficiency

docx_questions.text: Cystic fibrosis is caused by which process?
Between which months of age does sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS) most often occur?
Where in the respiratory tract do the majority of foreign objects aspirated by children finally lodge?
What is the most common predisposing factor to obstructive sleep apnea in children?
options: 𝛼. Chronic respiratory infections c. Obligatory mouth breathing 𝗉. Adenotonsillar hypertrophy d. Paradoxic breathing
